item.title: Conclusion
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description: This has been a short guide of all the advanced rockbox theming things I know. Hopefully this helps people new to rockbox, and myself in the future when I return to making themes and inevitably forget everything. Thanks for reading!
item.content:encoded: This has been a short guide of all the advanced rockbox theming things I know. Hopefully this helps people new to rockbox, and myself in the future when I return to making themes and inevitably forget everything. Thanks for reading!

item.title: 4. Unused Functions
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
∘ The xd tag -   This might seem like an odd choice, the most used tag of all? But it actually has a different way using it that’s almost never used! The usual way is labelling images by a single letter, this is incredibly handy for writing stuff like battery indicators manually. However, the label can actual be anything you want! As written here on the Wiki:

  %xd(label, <subimage number> [, offset])

  Using the tag like this opens a huge amount of functionality, as well as making your code more readable. If you replace the offset part with a tag like %mm for playback mode, it will automatically display the corresponding icon for the right mode of playback.

∘ Recording Screen Tags -   Surprisingly not in the manual for the iPod 5th gen, the Recording Screen has an array of tags available for theming and providing the user additional information. You can see the full list of functions on the Wiki here

One additional function that can be used here is the %pR and %pL Tags. When used in a Bar tag config, will show the frequency input graph while recording.

∘ Drawing the main viewport as a skin - This feature is a relatively recent addition to rockbox, it’s also quite unfinished and buggy. However, in it’s current state the things possible are quite impressive!

  The one person pushing these new features in themes is P Poorten, their themes PI5 and wavy both use this feature to create some incredibly interesting interfaces. To see the full list of the Tags, see the Wiki here.
item.content:encoded:
∘ The xd tag -   This might seem like an odd choice, the most used tag of all? But it actually has a different way using it that’s almost never used! The usual way is labelling images by a single letter, this is incredibly handy for writing stuff like battery indicators manually. However, the label can actual be anything you want! As written here on the Wiki:

  %xd(label, <subimage number> [, offset])

  Using the tag like this opens a huge amount of functionality, as well as making your code more readable. If you replace the offset part with a tag like %mm for playback mode, it will automatically display the corresponding icon for the right mode of playback.

∘ Recording Screen Tags -   Surprisingly not in the manual for the iPod 5th gen, the Recording Screen has an array of tags available for theming and providing the user additional information. You can see the full list of functions on the Wiki here

One additional function that can be used here is the %pR and %pL Tags. When used in a Bar tag config, will show the frequency input graph while recording.

∘ Drawing the main viewport as a skin - This feature is a relatively recent addition to rockbox, it’s also quite unfinished and buggy. However, in it’s current state the things possible are quite impressive!

  The one person pushing these new features in themes is P Poorten, their themes PI5 and wavy both use this feature to create some incredibly interesting interfaces. To see the full list of the Tags, see the Wiki here.

item.title: 3. Overlay Images
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
Drawing overlays in Rockbox is a neat trick to mask sections of the screen to create unique interface designs. While mostly used to create rounded corners on album art, the technique can actually be applied to any part of the screen.

How it works

  Rockbox sees a specific RGB Value as transparent (another value it sees as the foreground colour) you can read more about it in the Notes of this section of the Wiki. By putting these into our images, they can have transparent sections. Do however make sure your images are properly formatted to avoid errors, using Gimp this means exporting your images using the 16-bits, R5 G6 B5 option.

Interesting applications

In my own theme, adwaitapod, I used overlays ontop of the main viewport to create rounded corners. Everytime a new item is selected, the overlay refreshes which sometimes has a visible lag before it reappears, however usually this isn’t an issue.

I also used the idea to solve a problem for someone else who wanted to have a squared scrollbar, using one pixel images to mask the corners of the default scrollbar. In situations like these, make sure to use the Cyan colour so it will be drawn as the foreground colour.

Lastly, lets look at some lesser-used functions in Rockbox.
item.content:encoded:
Drawing overlays in Rockbox is a neat trick to mask sections of the screen to create unique interface designs. While mostly used to create rounded corners on album art, the technique can actually be applied to any part of the screen.

How it works

  Rockbox sees a specific RGB Value as transparent (another value it sees as the foreground colour) you can read more about it in the Notes of this section of the Wiki. By putting these into our images, they can have transparent sections. Do however make sure your images are properly formatted to avoid errors, using Gimp this means exporting your images using the 16-bits, R5 G6 B5 option.

Interesting applications

In my own theme, adwaitapod, I used overlays ontop of the main viewport to create rounded corners. Everytime a new item is selected, the overlay refreshes which sometimes has a visible lag before it reappears, however usually this isn’t an issue.

I also used the idea to solve a problem for someone else who wanted to have a squared scrollbar, using one pixel images to mask the corners of the default scrollbar. In situations like these, make sure to use the Cyan colour so it will be drawn as the foreground colour.

Lastly, lets look at some lesser-used functions in Rockbox.

item.title: 2. Lockscreen
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
There’s a rich history of Rockbox themes using the hold switch for additional functionality, however they followed the idea of showing extra info, or displaying album art. In comparison, Yuuiko uses the hold switch to unlock entirely unique screens in a way that enhances the capabilities of Rockbox.

How it works

  The setup for lockscreens is surprisingly simple. It takes the same concept of background switching we’ve seen, but combines it with the function for the hold switch, allowing us to define what should be displayed when the switch is on and off!

FreshOS.sbs - By Yuuiko
#
%xl(E,Backdrop - LOCK.bmp,0,0)
%xl(P,Backdrop - HOME.bmp,0,0)
#
%?if(%cs, =, 1)<%?mh<%xd(E)|%xd(P)>> #HOME
%?if(%cs, =, 1)<%?mh<%VI(u)%Vd(q)%Vd(q)|%VI(w)%Vd(m)%Vd(q)>> #Home

 Here we can see two %?if functions that control the lockscreen, the first changes the backdrop and the second controls which viewports to show.

Limitations

  Sadly, these features don’t come without some flaws. Some are easy to work around, though others require hacks that aren’t fully tested.

∘ Album Art -  Rockbox is unable to display album art in more than one viewport. Therefore if you intend to have album art on your home screen and on your lockscreen, then you’ll have to have them in the exact same spot. You can see Yuuiko’s themes for a better example.

∘ Blank main viewport -  When returning from the lockscreen to the home menu, the main viewport (which shows the menu items) wont load. Once you scroll, it will refresh and show the items again. There’s no workaround for this, the only thing you can do is let the user know what to do.

FreshOS.sbs - By Yuuiko
#
%Vl(m,0,22,320,218,-)%Vf(601D3A)



   scroll the
   clickwheel.

  The distance here matters, as it will determine the position of the text on the screen. When you scroll, the message no longer becomes visible.

∘ Playing Music -  If your ipod changes onto the next song while on the lockscreen, the screen will bug out a little. The main viewport will draw itself over the backdrop, but under any draw elements on the screen. There have been some solutions experimented with, like drawing a viewport full of the current second functions to update the desired area every second. However these haven’t been tested, and could possibly take a hit on battery life.

 Next, we’ll be taking a look at images and how to use overlays more.
item.content:encoded:
There’s a rich history of Rockbox themes using the hold switch for additional functionality, however they followed the idea of showing extra info, or displaying album art. In comparison, Yuuiko uses the hold switch to unlock entirely unique screens in a way that enhances the capabilities of Rockbox.

How it works

  The setup for lockscreens is surprisingly simple. It takes the same concept of background switching we’ve seen, but combines it with the function for the hold switch, allowing us to define what should be displayed when the switch is on and off!

FreshOS.sbs - By Yuuiko
#
%xl(E,Backdrop - LOCK.bmp,0,0)
%xl(P,Backdrop - HOME.bmp,0,0)
#
%?if(%cs, =, 1)<%?mh<%xd(E)|%xd(P)>> #HOME
%?if(%cs, =, 1)<%?mh<%VI(u)%Vd(q)%Vd(q)|%VI(w)%Vd(m)%Vd(q)>> #Home

 Here we can see two %?if functions that control the lockscreen, the first changes the backdrop and the second controls which viewports to show.

Limitations

  Sadly, these features don’t come without some flaws. Some are easy to work around, though others require hacks that aren’t fully tested.

∘ Album Art -  Rockbox is unable to display album art in more than one viewport. Therefore if you intend to have album art on your home screen and on your lockscreen, then you’ll have to have them in the exact same spot. You can see Yuuiko’s themes for a better example.

∘ Blank main viewport -  When returning from the lockscreen to the home menu, the main viewport (which shows the menu items) wont load. Once you scroll, it will refresh and show the items again. There’s no workaround for this, the only thing you can do is let the user know what to do.

FreshOS.sbs - By Yuuiko
#
%Vl(m,0,22,320,218,-)%Vf(601D3A)



   scroll the
   clickwheel.

  The distance here matters, as it will determine the position of the text on the screen. When you scroll, the message no longer becomes visible.

∘ Playing Music -  If your ipod changes onto the next song while on the lockscreen, the screen will bug out a little. The main viewport will draw itself over the backdrop, but under any draw elements on the screen. There have been some solutions experimented with, like drawing a viewport full of the current second functions to update the desired area every second. However these haven’t been tested, and could possibly take a hit on battery life.

 Next, we’ll be taking a look at images and how to use overlays more.

item.title: 1. Backdrop Switching
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
When it comes to making more advanced themes, switching backdrops is the door to most things. At it’s core, it essentially involves using Rockbox’s “current screen” tag to decide which backdrop gets displayed on which screen. Here’s a list of all the available screens and their corresponding numbers:

No.| Screen
1 - Main Menu
2 - WPS (Music screen)
3 - Recording screen
4 - FM Radio screen
5 - Current Playlist screen
6 - Settings menus
7 - File browser
8 - Database browser
9 - Plugin browser
10 - Quickscreen
11 - Pitchscreen
12 - Setting chooser
13 - Playlist Catalogue Viewer
14 - Plugin
15 - Context menu
16 - System Info screen
17 - Time and Date Screen
18 - Bookmark browser
19 - Shortcuts menu
20 - Track Info screen
21 - USB Screen

Using the Function

Usually this function is used in either of the following ways:

1| %?if(%cs, =, 21)<%V(True)|%V(False)>
 | #      or
2| %?if(%cs, !=, 21)<%?if(%cs, !=, 10)<<%V(True)|%V(False)>>>

The “%?if()” function at the start polls the “%cs” function to see if it is (or in no.2, isn’t) equal to 21, and different functions can be triggered depending on whether the answer is true or false. The second function uses the “not equal to” or “!=” operator, to determine if something should be displayed when a screen isn’t the 21st or 10th screen (this can be stacked.)

Making it all work

  When it comes to putting everything together, the key is to get the right setup. While there is something similar in FreshOS by Yuuiko, I’ve had much more success with a method best seen in David Barkan’s theme AMusicPod. Which looks like the following:

#Load Background
%V(0,0,-,-,-)%VB
%x(Da,backdrop home_g.bmp,0,0)
%V(0,0,-,-,-)
#
#USB Screen
%?if(%cs, =, 21)<%xd(M)>
%Vi(m,0,0,1,1,-)

You can read more about how it all works here. Without this, your viewports will mess up displaying white, or white backgrounds. The last “%V(0,0,-,-,-)” isn’t always needed, however if you intended to follow the next section and build a lockscreen, then you will need it to make that work.
item.content:encoded:
When it comes to making more advanced themes, switching backdrops is the door to most things. At it’s core, it essentially involves using Rockbox’s “current screen” tag to decide which backdrop gets displayed on which screen. Here’s a list of all the available screens and their corresponding numbers:

No.| Screen
1 - Main Menu
2 - WPS (Music screen)
3 - Recording screen
4 - FM Radio screen
5 - Current Playlist screen
6 - Settings menus
7 - File browser
8 - Database browser
9 - Plugin browser
10 - Quickscreen
11 - Pitchscreen
12 - Setting chooser
13 - Playlist Catalogue Viewer
14 - Plugin
15 - Context menu
16 - System Info screen
17 - Time and Date Screen
18 - Bookmark browser
19 - Shortcuts menu
20 - Track Info screen
21 - USB Screen

Using the Function

Usually this function is used in either of the following ways:

1| %?if(%cs, =, 21)<%V(True)|%V(False)>
 | #      or
2| %?if(%cs, !=, 21)<%?if(%cs, !=, 10)<<%V(True)|%V(False)>>>

The “%?if()” function at the start polls the “%cs” function to see if it is (or in no.2, isn’t) equal to 21, and different functions can be triggered depending on whether the answer is true or false. The second function uses the “not equal to” or “!=” operator, to determine if something should be displayed when a screen isn’t the 21st or 10th screen (this can be stacked.)

Making it all work

  When it comes to putting everything together, the key is to get the right setup. While there is something similar in FreshOS by Yuuiko, I’ve had much more success with a method best seen in David Barkan’s theme AMusicPod. Which looks like the following:

#Load Background
%V(0,0,-,-,-)%VB
%x(Da,backdrop home_g.bmp,0,0)
%V(0,0,-,-,-)
#
#USB Screen
%?if(%cs, =, 21)<%xd(M)>
%Vi(m,0,0,1,1,-)

You can read more about how it all works here. Without this, your viewports will mess up displaying white, or white backgrounds. The last “%V(0,0,-,-,-)” isn’t always needed, however if you intended to follow the next section and build a lockscreen, then you will need it to make that work.

item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description: Without even realising it, I went on a bit of an internet detox this weekend. My phone’s gone almost 50 hours on a single charge, which is pretty good. I spent most of the weekend between working on some new design projects and watching the wildlife in our garden. It’s really become a sanctuary for so many different kinds of species, I even found a threatened leaf-cutter bee building a nest which was amazing to watch. I’m somewhat reluctant to return to social media yet, I think I’ll keep riding this wave for a while longer.
item.content:encoded: Without even realising it, I went on a bit of an internet detox this weekend. My phone’s gone almost 50 hours on a single charge, which is pretty good. I spent most of the weekend between working on some new design projects and watching the wildlife in our garden. It’s really become a sanctuary for so many different kinds of species, I even found a threatened leaf-cutter bee building a nest which was amazing to watch. I’m somewhat reluctant to return to social media yet, I think I’ll keep riding this wave for a while longer.

item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description: Had some really hot weather today, spent most of the day in and out between the garden and my laptop. Started work designing a typeface for pebble watches based on their icon style. Looking to convert it into a watchface soon.
item.content:encoded: Had some really hot weather today, spent most of the day in and out between the garden and my laptop. Started work designing a typeface for pebble watches based on their icon style. Looking to convert it into a watchface soon.

item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description: I’ve gotten interested this week in propagating seeds from wildflowers in our garden. There’s a beautiful pink poppy with massive seed pods, as well as a bunch of bluebells that I’d love to spread to other places. I was considering drying and saving the seed, following this guide from realseeds, however I don’t think there’s much reason to in this situation.
item.content:encoded: I’ve gotten interested this week in propagating seeds from wildflowers in our garden. There’s a beautiful pink poppy with massive seed pods, as well as a bunch of bluebells that I’d love to spread to other places. I was considering drying and saving the seed, following this guide from realseeds, however I don’t think there’s much reason to in this situation.

item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description: Felt inspired to create a short form journal for the site after seeing some people on Mastodon doing the same. Excited to write more in it, hopefully this will also encourage me to update the site more! :3
item.content:encoded: Felt inspired to create a short form journal for the site after seeing some people on Mastodon doing the same. Excited to write more in it, hopefully this will also encourage me to update the site more! :3

item.title: Bandcamp Buyin' 2022
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
In an attempt to move away from music streaming, every month of 2022 I bought an album on Bandcamp. Some are favourites of mine, others only just released and are new to me.

∙ Follow me on Bandcamp.

The List

  • ∘ January:   Fool - McGee.
  • ∘ February:   Who Really Cares - TV Girl.
  • ∘ March:   Invitation to Her's - Her's.
  • ∘ April:   DELI DAYDREAMS - Kojaque.
  • ∘ May:   Sex & Food - Unknown Mortal Ochestra.
  • ∘ June:   Oncle Jazz - Men I Trust.
item.content:encoded:
In an attempt to move away from music streaming, every month of 2022 I bought an album on Bandcamp. Some are favourites of mine, others only just released and are new to me.

∙ Follow me on Bandcamp.

The List

  • ∘ January:   Fool - McGee.
  • ∘ February:   Who Really Cares - TV Girl.
  • ∘ March:   Invitation to Her's - Her's.
  • ∘ April:   DELI DAYDREAMS - Kojaque.
  • ∘ May:   Sex & Food - Unknown Mortal Ochestra.
  • ∘ June:   Oncle Jazz - Men I Trust.

item.title: Font Combining
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
This is a method of combining two different .ttf fonts into one. Useful for making CJK supported fonts for Rockbox, or adding glyphs into a font for web purposes etc. Fontforge is the main application used, however if you intend to make fonts for Rockbox, you’ll need convttf from their dev tools. This guide focuses on combining CJK fonts with non-CJK fonts.

Preparing the Secondary Font

  • ∘ Download language specific .otf file - The best font to use here is Noto CJK. However make sure you download the Region Specific Subset OTF file for each language you want.
  • ∘ Open the file in Fontforge and flatten CID Layers.
  • ∘ Remove any unnecessary characters (non-CJK letters, emoji etc.)
  • ∘ Re-encode as Unicode Full.
  • ∘ Save as *.sfd.

Combining the Fonts

  • ∘ Open the Base Font, which we want to combine with.
  • ∘ Remove any unnecessary characters, like emoji.
  • ∘ Go to Element > Merge Fonts choose the .sfd Font we just made, and merge.
  • ∘ Go to Edit > Select > Changed Glyphs.
  • ∘ Go to Element > Transform and select Scale.
  • ∘ Select Origin: Glyph Origin > Scale: 250% 250% > select all boxes. (Note: Scale will differ on the font, so experiment)
  • ∘ Export the font by going to File > Make Font choose true type and validate.

Making Rockbox Fonts

  • ∘ Start by cloning the Rockbox Github.
  • ∘ In the tools folder, use Element > make convttf.
  • - If you encounter errors with this, make sure "freetype-devel" and "freetype2" (or "ftgl") are installed.
    •  
  • ∘ To make the font, use ./convttf -p size -c 1 fontname.ttf.
  • - size should be the size of the font you want, this isn't however in pt or px, so experimentation is required.
  • - -c is the spacing between letters, 1 is an all round good option for most sizes and fonts
  • - If you want to have a padded font like seen in Interpod, use -Ta '-3' -Td '-2'. Ta being the top padding, and Td being the bottom, these values should be negative.
item.content:encoded:
This is a method of combining two different .ttf fonts into one. Useful for making CJK supported fonts for Rockbox, or adding glyphs into a font for web purposes etc. Fontforge is the main application used, however if you intend to make fonts for Rockbox, you’ll need convttf from their dev tools. This guide focuses on combining CJK fonts with non-CJK fonts.

Preparing the Secondary Font

  • ∘ Download language specific .otf file - The best font to use here is Noto CJK. However make sure you download the Region Specific Subset OTF file for each language you want.
  • ∘ Open the file in Fontforge and flatten CID Layers.
  • ∘ Remove any unnecessary characters (non-CJK letters, emoji etc.)
  • ∘ Re-encode as Unicode Full.
  • ∘ Save as *.sfd.

Combining the Fonts

  • ∘ Open the Base Font, which we want to combine with.
  • ∘ Remove any unnecessary characters, like emoji.
  • ∘ Go to Element > Merge Fonts choose the .sfd Font we just made, and merge.
  • ∘ Go to Edit > Select > Changed Glyphs.
  • ∘ Go to Element > Transform and select Scale.
  • ∘ Select Origin: Glyph Origin > Scale: 250% 250% > select all boxes. (Note: Scale will differ on the font, so experiment)
  • ∘ Export the font by going to File > Make Font choose true type and validate.

Making Rockbox Fonts

  • ∘ Start by cloning the Rockbox Github.
  • ∘ In the tools folder, use Element > make convttf.
  • - If you encounter errors with this, make sure "freetype-devel" and "freetype2" (or "ftgl") are installed.
    •  
  • ∘ To make the font, use ./convttf -p size -c 1 fontname.ttf.
  • - size should be the size of the font you want, this isn't however in pt or px, so experimentation is required.
  • - -c is the spacing between letters, 1 is an all round good option for most sizes and fonts
  • - If you want to have a padded font like seen in Interpod, use -Ta '-3' -Td '-2'. Ta being the top padding, and Td being the bottom, these values should be negative.

item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
March

  • ∘ Doing a big clean-out of everything I own.
  • ∘ Hopefully picking up where I left off learning the Linux Command Line.
  • ∘ Heading on my first break away in years, hoping to get some nice shots in a new environment.

April

  • ∘ Making a custom theme for my Rockbox iPod.
  • ∘ Burning loads of CDs to Digital for my music collection.
  • ∘ Mostly taking the month to rest and get back on my toes after a terrible health month.

May

  • ∘ Still working on the Rockbox adwaita theme.
  • ∘ Got an ereader!
  • ∘ Set up Shell scripts to download manga in ereader formats.
  • ∘ Started designing Origami again for the first time in years.

June

  • ∘ Finishing up my Rockbox theme for release.
  • ∘ Updating and upgrading the website.
  • ∘ Writing a guide to Rockbox theming.
  • ∘ Hoping to take some more time to read this month.
item.content:encoded:
March

  • ∘ Doing a big clean-out of everything I own.
  • ∘ Hopefully picking up where I left off learning the Linux Command Line.
  • ∘ Heading on my first break away in years, hoping to get some nice shots in a new environment.

April

  • ∘ Making a custom theme for my Rockbox iPod.
  • ∘ Burning loads of CDs to Digital for my music collection.
  • ∘ Mostly taking the month to rest and get back on my toes after a terrible health month.

May

  • ∘ Still working on the Rockbox adwaita theme.
  • ∘ Got an ereader!
  • ∘ Set up Shell scripts to download manga in ereader formats.
  • ∘ Started designing Origami again for the first time in years.

June

  • ∘ Finishing up my Rockbox theme for release.
  • ∘ Updating and upgrading the website.
  • ∘ Writing a guide to Rockbox theming.
  • ∘ Hoping to take some more time to read this month.

item.title: adwaitapod
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
Adwaitapod is a modern and feature-rich theme for iPod Video models running Rockbox. The theme uses the principles of Gnome’s Adwaita design language, and aims to be a complete and pleasing experience for users.

Features

  • ∘ Consistent interface with rounded corners.
  • ∘ Custom Lockscreen when the Hold switch is on in the main menu, or when USB is connected.
  • ∘ Radio Player skin with station icon support when using an FM Presets file.
  • ∘ Custom Recording screen with extra indicators for file format and frequency selected.
  • ∘ Miniplayer that appears on the main screen as well as the quick screen.
  • ∘ Lossless format file indicator for the Player screen.
  • ∘ Separate "Dark mode" theme available too.

Extras

 Extras available via the Github Repo include:

  • ∘ Fonts with CJK support, including full theme downloads including them.
  • ∘ Releases with settings for smooth scrolling text (can't be uploaded to Rockbox).
  • ∘ Copies of the theme's code with labelling.
  • ∘ Inkscape SVG files of every individual screen in the theme.

Download

  • ⬩ Adwaitapod download.
  • ⬩ Adwaitapod Dark download.
  • ⬩ Github Repository.
  • ⬩ Rockbox Theme page.
  • ⬩ Rockbox Dark Theme page.

Gallery

 All images are an SVG recreation of how the theme looks. For screenshots of the theme running on hardware, see the Rockbox Themes page.

Credit

 Credit to the GNOME Project for the adwaita icons used in this theme, as well to the authors of the Cantarell Typeface Font.
item.content:encoded:
Adwaitapod is a modern and feature-rich theme for iPod Video models running Rockbox. The theme uses the principles of Gnome’s Adwaita design language, and aims to be a complete and pleasing experience for users.

Features

  • ∘ Consistent interface with rounded corners.
  • ∘ Custom Lockscreen when the Hold switch is on in the main menu, or when USB is connected.
  • ∘ Radio Player skin with station icon support when using an FM Presets file.
  • ∘ Custom Recording screen with extra indicators for file format and frequency selected.
  • ∘ Miniplayer that appears on the main screen as well as the quick screen.
  • ∘ Lossless format file indicator for the Player screen.
  • ∘ Separate "Dark mode" theme available too.

Extras

 Extras available via the Github Repo include:

  • ∘ Fonts with CJK support, including full theme downloads including them.
  • ∘ Releases with settings for smooth scrolling text (can't be uploaded to Rockbox).
  • ∘ Copies of the theme's code with labelling.
  • ∘ Inkscape SVG files of every individual screen in the theme.

Download

  • ⬩ Adwaitapod download.
  • ⬩ Adwaitapod Dark download.
  • ⬩ Github Repository.
  • ⬩ Rockbox Theme page.
  • ⬩ Rockbox Dark Theme page.

Gallery

 All images are an SVG recreation of how the theme looks. For screenshots of the theme running on hardware, see the Rockbox Themes page.

Credit

 Credit to the GNOME Project for the adwaita icons used in this theme, as well to the authors of the Cantarell Typeface Font.

item.title: Reusing Technology
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
Our world has a tech waste problem

  There’s really no hiding the fact. Our world is built around fast fashion and fast tech, we buy and we throw out. Because of this, there’s loads of old, unused phones and other bits lying around the house that I’ve sought to utilise and solve problems with.

Smartphone Alarm Clock

  My first smartphone was this Nokia 530 running Windows Phone. I still have a huge soft spot for it, being small, light and bright it’s hard not to have a smile on your face using it. Windows Phone 8 is an OS still unbeaten in simplicity and function, it’s live tiles are a big favourite of mine. I’ve used this phone recently for college emails and calender, to keep college life physically separate. During this time I got into the habit of using the phone as alarm clock, and still do despite not using it for college stuff anymore. Some strict settings are in place to draw out the 1430mAh battery, including Airplane mode, constant battery saver mode, low brightness and turning off the phone while I’m awake. All this has given me roughly 40 days on a single charge which is quite nice. On android devices, I think deeper changes could be made in order to out even more draw battery life for an alarm clock.

Media / Music Player

  When I used to run the Samsung Core Prime while I was in school, I made a nice TV-style box to fit it to watch stuff on it with. After getting a new phone, it still gets used! Especially for music it can be extremely useful to have a device hooked up to speakers. If you use Spotify, you can turn wired speakers into “smart” ones, controlling the music on another phone or computer. Building display boxes like this for smartphones is a great idea for making digital photo frames or movie players around the house, though battery life can sometimes be a bit dismal on older devices if their screens are always running.

Modification and new Software

  Modifying devices has become more and more popular over the years, today it’s possible to completely rebuild a Gameboy from the ground up with a modern display, better audio and a fancy shell to boot! Products like iFlash give new life to iPods, with faster, more reliable flash storage over old mini hard-drives. Replacement firmware Rockbox is also extremely popular upgrade for various media players. There’s also fantastic projects like Hundred Rabbit’s Uxn ecosystem of smol tools and games. Uxn runs on many systems, even being ported to the Nintendo GBA and DS. The system has many fun tools like noodle a useful drawing app, a cute catclock and orca a livecoding environment used for making music. Uxn aims to give practical use to older, low-powered devices as well as newer ones that may otherwise be thrown away.
item.content:encoded:
Our world has a tech waste problem

  There’s really no hiding the fact. Our world is built around fast fashion and fast tech, we buy and we throw out. Because of this, there’s loads of old, unused phones and other bits lying around the house that I’ve sought to utilise and solve problems with.

Smartphone Alarm Clock

  My first smartphone was this Nokia 530 running Windows Phone. I still have a huge soft spot for it, being small, light and bright it’s hard not to have a smile on your face using it. Windows Phone 8 is an OS still unbeaten in simplicity and function, it’s live tiles are a big favourite of mine. I’ve used this phone recently for college emails and calender, to keep college life physically separate. During this time I got into the habit of using the phone as alarm clock, and still do despite not using it for college stuff anymore. Some strict settings are in place to draw out the 1430mAh battery, including Airplane mode, constant battery saver mode, low brightness and turning off the phone while I’m awake. All this has given me roughly 40 days on a single charge which is quite nice. On android devices, I think deeper changes could be made in order to out even more draw battery life for an alarm clock.

Media / Music Player

  When I used to run the Samsung Core Prime while I was in school, I made a nice TV-style box to fit it to watch stuff on it with. After getting a new phone, it still gets used! Especially for music it can be extremely useful to have a device hooked up to speakers. If you use Spotify, you can turn wired speakers into “smart” ones, controlling the music on another phone or computer. Building display boxes like this for smartphones is a great idea for making digital photo frames or movie players around the house, though battery life can sometimes be a bit dismal on older devices if their screens are always running.

Modification and new Software

  Modifying devices has become more and more popular over the years, today it’s possible to completely rebuild a Gameboy from the ground up with a modern display, better audio and a fancy shell to boot! Products like iFlash give new life to iPods, with faster, more reliable flash storage over old mini hard-drives. Replacement firmware Rockbox is also extremely popular upgrade for various media players. There’s also fantastic projects like Hundred Rabbit’s Uxn ecosystem of smol tools and games. Uxn runs on many systems, even being ported to the Nintendo GBA and DS. The system has many fun tools like noodle a useful drawing app, a cute catclock and orca a livecoding environment used for making music. Uxn aims to give practical use to older, low-powered devices as well as newer ones that may otherwise be thrown away.

item.title: Ecovillages
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
Wikipedia describes an Ecovillage as “..a traditional or intentional community with the goal of becoming more socially, culturally, economically, and/or ecologically sustainable”, which perfectly describes the community in Cloughjordan EcoVillage. The village, which spreads over 67 acres, houses an amphitheatre, a large community farm, the riot rye bakery, a hostel and even a lovely bookstore that specialises in permaculture, sustainable living and activism.

Village Characteristics

Cloughjordan Ecovillage has a large variety in housing, near the village entrance are a number of spacey apartment blocks surrounding the town square. As you go further in, there are mostly individual plots with houses of much variety in construction, most following an eco philosophy. There are many walking trails to houses off the main paths and roads. Trees encase these trails beautifully (see the images below for an example). Overall, nature is very much in control around these houses. There are no managed lawns or unfamiliar plants to be seen.

Energy and Waste Management

  The village has an installation of a 500m² solar panel array, and every building appears to have their own installations of some kind of panel. In terms of waste management, the village is dependent on the local council water treatment facilities. This dependency however has stopped the village from expanding, the facilities being at max capacity means they must either find their own solutions or work with the government to improve the system already in place, which they appear to be doing.

Final Thoughts

The Ecovillage is a fascinating place, it’s calm, peaceful soundscape adds to the way of life there. The village is host to many interesting people, and equally interesting projects. It’s a host for a boom of culture and nature that meets the goals of the original project.

Further Links

  • ∙ Cloughjordan Ecovillage.
  • ∙ Resident Bruce Darrel's youtube channel on farming.
  • ∙ The local Fablab.
  • ∙ Ecovillage Wikipedia page.

Gallery

item.title: Lough Derg
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
I spent a week around Lough Derg in March 2022. Staying in Dromineer, the village was host to a decently sized Marina, a castle ruins as well as a 10th century church. The area surrounding the lake are full of forest trails and castles galore. The roads in the locality are part of a larger cycling trail.

Photos around the Lough
item.content:encoded:

The area surrounding the lake are full of forest trails and castles galore. The roads in the locality are part of a larger cycling trail.

Photos around the Lough

item.title: Colophon
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
A comprehensive dive into the design, and creation of this website

Background

  This site was made to scratch an itch I long had. Sharing stuff on social media has never been my mojo, I’ll often post my photography, however I yearned for something more expansive and exciting so I made a website.

  The first version of the site was made by modifying what I felt was a suitable theme, however I soon became aware of my lack of knowledge in web design and development, scrapping the site soon after I finished it. This current version has been built from scratch, using Hugo as a method of generating files offline to upload to github.

Inspiration

  Lizbeth Poirier’s beautiful site Ritual Dust was a big inspiration and help when designing the site, Lizbeth has an incredibly helpful collection of resources that I learned a lot from including Fonts, Html and Css. Thomasorus’ Html Tips guide is a must read if your building your own site with minimal knowledge. Without it, I wouldn’t have used Flexboxes or known how to properly organise my code.

Site Philosophy

  This site was made with two things in mind: Fun and Accessibility. Each section has it’s own, vibrant theme using Thomasorus’ beautiful css theming solution. The code was also designed with simplicity in mind, there is no javascript used and every element is completely adaptive without the use of media queries. Lastly, all images are completely optimized for fast page loading, thanks to Rekka Bellum’s easy to follow guide! Most pages have 1080p images, but on the large gallery ones, images are reduced to 720p to help with bandwidth.

Fonts

  This site uses 3 different fonts. CMRDD Bold is used for links/clickable content. Barlow Black is used for all Headers. Finally, League Spartan is used for the text on the site. Each font is both free and open source, their licenses allowing for web use and modification. Font Squirrel’s Webfont generator was extremely useful in preparing the fonts for the website.

Future Additions

  While building the site, decisions were made to make the site more accessible via older browser (using Netsurf as a testing point). However, the theming system doesn’t work and there are some other tweaks I’d like to make to perfect it. On top of that, the accessibility of my website isn’t as good as it could be. Currently all images are captioned and correct etiquette was followed for page layouts, but I’d like to give people options to turn off custom theming and fonts. This however would likely involve adding javascript which I’m slightly reluctant on doing. But we’ll see.

A comprehensive dive into the design, and creation of this website

Background

  This site was made to scratch an itch I long had. Sharing stuff on social media has never been my mojo, I’ll often post my photography, however I yearned for something more expansive and exciting so I made a website.

  The first version of the site was made by modifying what I felt was a suitable theme, however I soon became aware of my lack of knowledge in web design and development, scrapping the site soon after I finished it. This current version has been built from scratch, using Hugo as a method of generating files offline to upload to github.

Inspiration

  Lizbeth Poirier’s beautiful site Ritual Dust was a big inspiration and help when designing the site, Lizbeth has an incredibly helpful collection of resources that I learned a lot from including Fonts, Html and Css. Thomasorus’ Html Tips guide is a must read if your building your own site with minimal knowledge. Without it, I wouldn’t have used Flexboxes or known how to properly organise my code.

Site Philosophy

  This site was made with two things in mind: Fun and Accessibility. Each section has it’s own, vibrant theme using Thomasorus’ beautiful css theming solution. The code was also designed with simplicity in mind, there is no javascript used and every element is completely adaptive without the use of media queries. Lastly, all images are completely optimized for fast page loading, thanks to Rekka Bellum’s easy to follow guide! Most pages have 1080p images, but on the large gallery ones, images are reduced to 720p to help with bandwidth.

Fonts

  This site uses 3 different fonts. CMRDD Bold is used for links/clickable content. Barlow Black is used for all Headers. Finally, League Spartan is used for the text on the site. Each font is both free and open source, their licenses allowing for web use and modification. Font Squirrel’s Webfont generator was extremely useful in preparing the fonts for the website.

Future Additions

  While building the site, decisions were made to make the site more accessible via older browser (using Netsurf as a testing point). However, the theming system doesn’t work and there are some other tweaks I’d like to make to perfect it. On top of that, the accessibility of my website isn’t as good as it could be. Currently all images are captioned and correct etiquette was followed for page layouts, but I’d like to give people options to turn off custom theming and fonts. This however would likely involve adding javascript which I’m slightly reluctant on doing. But we’ll see.

item.title: Streetwalker
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
Streetwalker was a project started in 2016 in an attempt to learn lua and the pico-8 virtual console. After experiencing Graphics Exercise by Mason Lindroth, I was inspired to create my own walking sim with the goal of filling the system’s 1024x512 pixel map space.

The game’s design takes heavy inspiration from digital maps as well as the brutalist architecture movement. Without any discernable differences from one place to the next, players are forced to wander and explore the world like they would with a new city. There are no gameplay objectives, however items are scattered randomly throughout the world. Within the world itself hides smaller narratives played out by small, colourless objects on the ground. The cylinders and cubes sharing this world with you.

  • ∙ Play Streetwalker.
  • ∙ Download the cart.
item.content:encoded:
Streetwalker was a project started in 2016 in an attempt to learn lua and the pico-8 virtual console. After experiencing Graphics Exercise by Mason Lindroth, I was inspired to create my own walking sim with the goal of filling the system’s 1024x512 pixel map space.

The game’s design takes heavy inspiration from digital maps as well as the brutalist architecture movement. Without any discernable differences from one place to the next, players are forced to wander and explore the world like they would with a new city. There are no gameplay objectives, however items are scattered randomly throughout the world. Within the world itself hides smaller narratives played out by small, colourless objects on the ground. The cylinders and cubes sharing this world with you.

  • ∙ Play Streetwalker.
  • ∙ Download the cart.

item.title: Virtual Gallery
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
The Virtual Gallery a website was born in the summer of 2020 after the cancellation of an exhibition that an art course I was attending hosted. Not wanting the work and effort of everyone I did the course with to go to waste, I set out to make a platform for them to share with their friends and family.

The Exhibition

Work took several months to build a basic site from scratch using HTML and CSS, largely due to my inexperience however I learned a lot. During this time the scope changed drastically, deciding to open it up to other young artists locally who wanted to share their work. In the end, 15 artists signed up to exhibit. Despite my inability to run proper social media for it, the exhibition was quite successful. While a follow-up photography competition was planned, circumstances preventing me from working on the site. I hope to pick the project back up from scratch in the future, however.

item.title: Origami
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
Origami is the art of folding paper into various forms and objects. There are many different kinds of Origami other than traditional folding including modular designs like the Kusudamas, wet folding which allows creative sculpting, or even weaving with strip folding.

The beautiful Origami Firework was the first design I ever made. Following a video tutorial, I struggled immensely to complete it but having no one to turn was an incredibly liberating experience as a teenager and the satisfaction of finishing it is something I still remember. The design is by Yami Yamauchi, and the diagrams can be found on Yami’s Corner.

Over the years, I have also designed several Origami creations of my own which you can see at the Origami Designs page.

Interesting Links

  • ∙ Jo Nakashima video tutorials.
  • ∙ Happy Folding diagram archive.
  • ∙ Russian Origami portal.
  • ∙ Robert J. Lang's Portfolio.
  • ∙ Ekatrerina Lukasheva's Portfolio.

Gallery

∙ Origami Bracelets   (Inna Creates’ Design)

∙ An ornate Sonobe 30 Kusudama.

∙ A decorative Kusudama with a tassel and crane.

item.title: Origami Designs
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
Origami Modular Festive Tree

The Origami festive tree is a modular origami tree with little slots in the leaves to put whatever you want! It was designed as a modular, flat-packable festive tree that could be practical, allowing you to put different decorations or items in it. The design still needs some tweaking before I’m happy with posting instructions, I’ll probably get around to it soon.

Origami Cat

This is my take on the origami cat design, there isn’t too much to say about it, the design itself isn’t all too complicated. Some parts like forming the face take a couple of light, unmarked folds on the sides. It’s so cute.
item.content:encoded:
Origami Modular Festive Tree

The Origami festive tree is a modular origami tree with little slots in the leaves to put whatever you want! It was designed as a modular, flat-packable festive tree that could be practical, allowing you to put different decorations or items in it. The design still needs some tweaking before I’m happy with posting instructions, I’ll probably get around to it soon.

Origami Cat

This is my take on the origami cat design, there isn’t too much to say about it, the design itself isn’t all too complicated. Some parts like forming the face take a couple of light, unmarked folds on the sides. It’s so cute.

item.title: Gamejams
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
Tiny-TV Jam

Tiny-TV Jam ran for a week in January 2017. The goal of the jam was to make a small game that fit within the 10x11 resolution of the TV in the pico-8 cart provided. I entered the jam almost by accident, having no programming knowledge, I had messed around with the cart and designed a detailed recreation of a Macintosh 128k pc. I decided to make a game, Tiny Cookie Clicker, and the jam provided some great design challenges. There wasn’t enough space for full size numbers, so I had to come up with a 2x3 number font. This was achieved using two colours. The game can only count to 60 as I was unable to work out a proper display system, and instead resorted to hand coding every number.

Game Maker’s Toolkit Jam 2019 (Only One)

Game Maker’s Toolkit jams always have interesting briefs every year that force you to think outside the box of what games can be. In 2019 the brief was simply “Only One”. Coming up with a concept for it was challenging, but I quickly had one. In “Z” players use the [Z] Key to move their character around the screen. When the button is held, a progress bar fills up at the top of the screen. Your player will move depending on where you let go as it fills up, the directions noted on their respective quarters. I felt this concept best fit a turn-based roguelike, adding an interesting twist to each turn. Sadly I ran out of time and didn’t manage to finish any proper game functions besides the movement demo.

  • ∙ Play Tiny Cookie Clicker.
  • ∙ Play Z demo.
item.content:encoded:
Tiny-TV Jam

Tiny-TV Jam ran for a week in January 2017. The goal of the jam was to make a small game that fit within the 10x11 resolution of the TV in the pico-8 cart provided. I entered the jam almost by accident, having no programming knowledge, I had messed around with the cart and designed a detailed recreation of a Macintosh 128k pc. I decided to make a game, Tiny Cookie Clicker, and the jam provided some great design challenges. There wasn’t enough space for full size numbers, so I had to come up with a 2x3 number font. This was achieved using two colours. The game can only count to 60 as I was unable to work out a proper display system, and instead resorted to hand coding every number.

Game Maker’s Toolkit Jam 2019 (Only One)

Game Maker’s Toolkit jams always have interesting briefs every year that force you to think outside the box of what games can be. In 2019 the brief was simply “Only One”. Coming up with a concept for it was challenging, but I quickly had one. In “Z” players use the [Z] Key to move their character around the screen. When the button is held, a progress bar fills up at the top of the screen. Your player will move depending on where you let go as it fills up, the directions noted on their respective quarters. I felt this concept best fit a turn-based roguelike, adding an interesting twist to each turn. Sadly I ran out of time and didn’t manage to finish any proper game functions besides the movement demo.

  • ∙ Play Tiny Cookie Clicker.
  • ∙ Play Z demo.

item.title: Famicase Exhibition
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
The Famicase Exhibition is an annual exhibition hosted by the Super Meteor store located in Tokyo, Japan. Entry is open to anyone worldwide, and the goal is create a cover for a fictional Famicom game of your creation.

Famicase Exhibition 2021 entry - Become

The 2021 Famicase Exhibition took place between April 29th and May 31st.

  • ∙ Famicase Website.
  • ∙ Purchase the Famicase 2021 Zine.
item.content:encoded:
The Famicase Exhibition is an annual exhibition hosted by the Super Meteor store located in Tokyo, Japan. Entry is open to anyone worldwide, and the goal is create a cover for a fictional Famicom game of your creation.

Famicase Exhibition 2021 entry - Become

The 2021 Famicase Exhibition took place between April 29th and May 31st.

  • ∙ Famicase Website.
  • ∙ Purchase the Famicase 2021 Zine.

item.title: Setup
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
A breakdown of the hardware and software I use for making things, or getting things done.

Hardware

∘ Lenovo Thinkpad E580 Laptop.

  • Cpu - Intel Core I5-8250U
  • Memory - 12GB
  • Storage - 256GB Samsung SSD
  • Display - 1920x1080 LCD
  • OS - Fedora Linux

∘ Keychron C1 Wired Keyboard.   The Keychron C1 is an 85%, Tenkeyless wired mechanical Keyboard. I bought it mostly for it’s low price, as well for it’s lack of wireless and light-up features. I very much enjoy using it.

∘ Logitech M185 Wireless Mouse.   A well used Wireless Mouse from 2012. Changed the batteries like twice or three times in the past.

∘ Basic Wacom Drawing Tablet.   No tilt detection, but decent pressure levels, 4 tablet buttons and 2 pen buttons. Pen doesn’t need batteries which is always a plus.

∘ Google Pixel 3a Phone.

  • OS - LineageOS 19
  • Battery - 3000mAh Battery

Camera

The Sony alpha 6000 is my main camera used for photography. I picked this mainly for it’s mirrorless, lightweight build. It has many features I’ve taken advantage of over the years, like it’s remote control app which is fantastic for long exposures with a tripod. I never shoot in RAW, only basic file formats as I don’t massively edit the complete photos in a conventional way, which you can read more about in my Trichrome post.

Software

Image Editing

∘ Krita.   A great, open source painting suite that does everything I need from it. I even edit my photos using it!

∘ Inkscape.   Whenever I work with SVGs or need to make diagrams, I always use Inkscape. It just works.

∘ Gimp.   Gimp isn’t the greatest of tools these days, however when you need to do specific things (like work with limiting colours etc.) it really comes in handy.

Text Editors

∘ Sublime Text.   When I couldn’t stand Visual Studio’s massive battery drain, I switched to the wonderful Sublime Text. With some add-ons for highlighting colours and some nice themes, and Sublime Text becomes a clear, simple workspace.

∘ Apostrophe.   A simple Markdown editor that I use for writing posts. Not much else to say about it!
item.content:encoded:
A breakdown of the hardware and software I use for making things, or getting things done.

Hardware

∘ Lenovo Thinkpad E580 Laptop.

  • Cpu - Intel Core I5-8250U
  • Memory - 12GB
  • Storage - 256GB Samsung SSD
  • Display - 1920x1080 LCD
  • OS - Fedora Linux

∘ Keychron C1 Wired Keyboard.   The Keychron C1 is an 85%, Tenkeyless wired mechanical Keyboard. I bought it mostly for it’s low price, as well for it’s lack of wireless and light-up features. I very much enjoy using it.

∘ Logitech M185 Wireless Mouse.   A well used Wireless Mouse from 2012. Changed the batteries like twice or three times in the past.

∘ Basic Wacom Drawing Tablet.   No tilt detection, but decent pressure levels, 4 tablet buttons and 2 pen buttons. Pen doesn’t need batteries which is always a plus.

∘ Google Pixel 3a Phone.

  • OS - LineageOS 19
  • Battery - 3000mAh Battery

Camera

The Sony alpha 6000 is my main camera used for photography. I picked this mainly for it’s mirrorless, lightweight build. It has many features I’ve taken advantage of over the years, like it’s remote control app which is fantastic for long exposures with a tripod. I never shoot in RAW, only basic file formats as I don’t massively edit the complete photos in a conventional way, which you can read more about in my Trichrome post.

Software

Image Editing

∘ Krita.   A great, open source painting suite that does everything I need from it. I even edit my photos using it!

∘ Inkscape.   Whenever I work with SVGs or need to make diagrams, I always use Inkscape. It just works.

∘ Gimp.   Gimp isn’t the greatest of tools these days, however when you need to do specific things (like work with limiting colours etc.) it really comes in handy.

Text Editors

∘ Sublime Text.   When I couldn’t stand Visual Studio’s massive battery drain, I switched to the wonderful Sublime Text. With some add-ons for highlighting colours and some nice themes, and Sublime Text becomes a clear, simple workspace.

∘ Apostrophe.   A simple Markdown editor that I use for writing posts. Not much else to say about it!

item.title: Trichrome Technique
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
Trichrome is a method of taking colour photography using different coloured filters (usually red, blue and green) to form a complete image. It was invented by Louis Ducos du Hauron in the late 19th century. It is most commonly used in black & white film photography to create atmospheric images, however the technique is usable with digital photography as well.

How does it work?

  Shooting trichrome is quite simple, firstly you need lenses. Red, blue and green are the best to start, but I have experimented with purple and yellow as well. A picture is taken for each colour, and then combined afterwards to form a complete image. For digital trichrome, I use any image editing software that has layer blending. Mess around and see what works! Below you can see a demonstration of the construction of a trichrome image.

Making your own lenses

Many photographers will point you towards often pricey acrylic lenses. However simple plastic, coloured vinyl sheets are a fantastic substitute for dirt cheap lenses. I made my frames out of cardboard, two layers at 90° to each other with the vinyl in the middle. The vinyl is stretched out like a canvas and super glued to the frames. They aren’t perfect though, the green and blue plastics I made leaked other colours pretty significantly. This can be fixed by double layering the vinyl, however I took it in it’s stride and the imperfections became the backbone of my personal technique. The one other downside is that rain and water will ruin them temporarily, this makes it impossible to shoot good photos in the rain sadly.

∙ Trichrome Photography Gallery
item.content:encoded:
Trichrome is a method of taking colour photography using different coloured filters (usually red, blue and green) to form a complete image. It was invented by Louis Ducos du Hauron in the late 19th century. It is most commonly used in black & white film photography to create atmospheric images, however the technique is usable with digital photography as well.

How does it work?

  Shooting trichrome is quite simple, firstly you need lenses. Red, blue and green are the best to start, but I have experimented with purple and yellow as well. A picture is taken for each colour, and then combined afterwards to form a complete image. For digital trichrome, I use any image editing software that has layer blending. Mess around and see what works! Below you can see a demonstration of the construction of a trichrome image.

Making your own lenses

Many photographers will point you towards often pricey acrylic lenses. However simple plastic, coloured vinyl sheets are a fantastic substitute for dirt cheap lenses. I made my frames out of cardboard, two layers at 90° to each other with the vinyl in the middle. The vinyl is stretched out like a canvas and super glued to the frames. They aren’t perfect though, the green and blue plastics I made leaked other colours pretty significantly. This can be fixed by double layering the vinyl, however I took it in it’s stride and the imperfections became the backbone of my personal technique. The one other downside is that rain and water will ruin them temporarily, this makes it impossible to shoot good photos in the rain sadly.

∙ Trichrome Photography Gallery

item.title: Beach Fossils
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
Beaches are filled with a vast number of different types of rocks and stones, but the ones that have always fascinated me are beach fossils. Fossil types can vary greatly based on your located, plants, shells and coral are all common types the can be found. Even chalk chunks are technically fossils!

In my area, coral fossils are by far the most common. I’ve found ones of different shapes, sizes and quantities. In ancient times, coral reefs formed around active volcanos, which would have been likely for the seas around Ireland.

(∙ British Geological Survey)

Interesting links

  • ∙ Earth Science Australia identification guide.
  • ∙ Examples of Fossils in Ireland.
  • ∙ Wikipedia: Rugosa, a common coral fossil type.

Fossil types can vary greatly based on your located, plants, shells and coral are all common types the can be found. Even chalk chunks are technically fossils!

In my area, coral fossils are by far the most common. I’ve found ones of different shapes, sizes and quantities. In ancient times, coral reefs formed around active volcanos, which would have been likely for the seas around Ireland.

item.title: Year Review 2021
item.dc:creator: Dook
item.description:
At a glance, this year has been a bit of a writeoff for me. I was diagnosed with Crohn’s earlier in the year and I’ve spent most of the rest recovering, going so far to drop out of college on medical leave. My high risk to covid has left me isolating in my home for a large amount of time as well. Both have hampered my ability to do much physical things, but allowed me to read and research more than I could before.

Hardware

  • ∘ Added a shelf to my desk to allow me to use my computer standing.
  • ∘ Bought a Pebble Time watch.
  • ∘ Repaired my Ds Lite and replaced it's shell with a snazzy Lime one.
  • ∘ Swapped my Thinkpad's old Hard-drive for a new SSD.

Software

  • ∘ Ditched Windows for Fedora Linux. Best choice of the year right here.
  • ∘ Went full Free Open Source Software on my phone.
  • ∘ Began using RSS feeds to compile my favoyrite sites and blogs in one place.
  • ∘ Started my blog!
  • ∘ Joined Mastodon for the first time.s

Favourite things

Music

∙ Mk.gee - Most listened artist of the year for me, fantastic producer though his bandcamp is missing his latest album sadly.

Podcasts

∙ Fall of Civilisations podcast - Fantastically engaging podcast that paints the fall of many civilisations in a concise, historical narrative.

∙ Panic Podcast - A podcast about the portland software company, Panic. Incredibly fun and enjoyable listen!

Websites

∙ Hundred Rabbits - A site covering Rek and Devine’s artist collective. I’ve spent so many hours reading on this site, with so many adventures, knowledge and projects to read about, it really is a treasure trove.

∙ Ritual dust - the personal site of Lizbeth Poirier, there’s a wide range of content to be found on it. From beautiful art, to recipes and the fabulously depthful folklore section that is an absolute joy to read, especially with the site’s fantastic design.

Youtube

∙ Disrupt - Disrupt’s tv-imitation aids greatly to it’s flowing narrative and visual style. The stories they cover are fascinating, and the videos themselves are incredibly well produced like nothing else I’ve seen on the platform.

∙ Not Just Bikes - this channel has fast become a favourite on Hacker News, where I first came across it. The highly informative videos make you rethink the old, pedestrian-unfriendly infrastructure so many countries continue to use.

Manga

∙ Yokohama Kaidashi Kikō - A peaceful, warm manga set in a world where humanity is in decline. An unforgettable read.

∙ Lore Olympus - There’s not much not to love about Lore Olympus. It’s style is vivid and easy to read, and it’s story engaging, really making you look forward for the next chapter.

Going Forward

The goal for 2022 is to get my health back into shape and sharpen my mind. I’d like to focus my time learning to properly program in a way that will actually be useful to me. The first project of the new year will likely be a rebuilding of this site, I’m unhappy hosting the site on github pages, not mention the code being an absolute mess. But I’ve got a clear vision of what I want to do this time, which makes it a lot easier to plan for. After that I plan to dabble in some C for the Pebble and make some watchfaces for a challenge.

Conclusion

This hasn’t been the best year ever, but I’m feeling more hopeful for next year! I’ve still got several months of free time left on leave so I’m eager to make the most of it. Here’s to a happy new year!

I was diagnosed with Crohn’s earlier in the year and I’ve spent most of the rest recovering, going so far to drop out of college on medical leave. My high risk to covid has left me isolating in my home for a large amount of time as well. Both have hampered my ability to do much physical things, but allowed me to read and research more than I could before.

  • ∘ Added a shelf to my desk to allow me to use my computer standing.
  • ∘ Bought a Pebble Time watch.

This hasn’t been the best year ever, but I’m feeling more hopeful for next year! I’ve still got several months of free time left on leave so I’m eager to make the most of it. Here’s to a happy new year!
